[[Giovanni Ferrero|Giovanni]] | parents = | website = {{URL|www.ferrero.com}} }} '''Maria Franca Fissolo''' (born 1941){{cite web|author=9 septembre 2016 |url=https://fr.express.live/2016/09/09/5-femmes-les-plus-riches-du-monde/2/ |title=Les 5 femmes les plus riches du monde - Page 2 de 5 - Express [FR] |website=Fr.express.live |date= |accessdate=30 September 2016}} is an Italian [[billionaire]], the widow of [[Michele Ferrero]], and the owner of [[Ferrero SpA]], Europe's second-largest [[confectionery]] company.{{cite book|author=Various|title=Hachette Children's Yearbook& Infopedia 2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2aq6CgAAQBAJ&pg=PT37|date=30 October 2015|publisher=Hachette India|isbn=978-93-5195-041-7|page=37}} ==Net worth== As of March 2018, ''[[Forbes]]'' estimated her net worth at $2.2 billion. ==Personal life== She married [[Michele Ferrero]] in 1962, and they had two sons together, Giovanni Ferrero and [[Pietro Ferrero Jr.]]{{cite news|author=John Hooper |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/feb/17/michele-ferrero |title=Michele Ferrero obituary | Business |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=19 January 2016}} She lives in [[Monaco]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fissolo, Maria Franca}} [[Category:1941 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Female billionaires]] [[Category:Ferrero family]] [[Category:Italian billionaires]] [[Category:Italian businesspeople]] [[Category:Italian expatriates in Monaco]] [[Category:People from Monte Carlo]]

{{Infobox person | name = May L. Cheney | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = May Lucretia Shepard | birth_date = {{Birth date|1862|5|11|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Garden Grove Township, Decatur County, Iowa]], United States | death_date = {{Death date and age|1942|4|22|1862|5|11|df=y}} | death_place = [[Berkeley, California]], United States | death_cause = | occupation = Appointment Secretary at [[University of California, Berkeley]]{{cite web| url=http://www.myacpa.org/may-l-cheney| title=May L. Cheney (1924–1925)|work=[[American College Personnel Association|ACPA]]}} | years_active= 1888–1938 | spouse = {{marriage| [[Lemuel Warren Cheney|Warren Cheney]]| 29 April 1883}} | children = Charles Henry Cheney,
[[Sheldon Warren Cheney]],
Marshall Chipman Cheney | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = American | ethnicity = | alma_mater = [[University of California, Berkeley]] | known_for = The first president of National Association of Appointment Secretaries (NAAS) now known as the [[American College Personnel Association]] (ACPA). | religion = | footnotes = }} '''May Lucretia Shepard Cheney''' (May 11, 1862 – April 22, 1942) was born during the Civil War in Garden Grove, Iowa, and was named after the month in which she was born, and her maternal grandmother who influenced her childhood. May's early school attendance was in her hometown. She attended high schools in Oakland and Chico, California before enrolling at [[University of California, Berkeley|UCB]] in 1879. With her widowed mother, she settled at ''2020 Hearst Avenue'' (then ''College Way''), in a house with a watermill in the rear yard.{{cite web| url=http://berkeleyheritage.com/berkeley_landmarks/cheney.html| title=U.C. offers the American Turgenev’s house for one dollar| work=[[Berkeley Architectural Heritage Association]]}} Residing in the same house was [[Lemuel Warren Cheney]] (1858–1921), a law student. The following year, the Shepards moved to 2316 Allston Way, across the street from the campus. Before long, Cheney had moved there too. The Shepards’ last address before May’s graduation in 1883 was Club House No. 4 on the university grounds, again shared by Cheney, now a journalist. In addition to their shared living quarters, May and Lemuel had a common interest in literature. Both belonged to the Neolaean Literary Society, of which May was vice-president.{{cite web| url=http://www.lib.berkeley.edu/uchistory/general_history/campuses/ucb/studentpubs.html| title=Berkeley: Student Publications| work=[[University of California, Berkeley Libraries]]}} On 29 April 1883, during her senior year, she married Cheney, the Bachelor of Letters degree was granted to her in December of that year. They left for Europe, where he served as [[Balkans|Balkan Peninsula]] correspondent for the [[San Francisco Chronicle]]. Their first son, Charles Henry Cheney, was born in Rome in February 1884. Upon their return she and her husband had a house built close to UCB, on College Avenue in [[Lodi, California|Lodi]]. In 1886, when she was 24 years old, May founded Cheney’s Pacific Coast Bureau of Education in [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]]. It was the first commercial teacher placement agency west of the Rockies, and her husband participated in its management. She decided that UCB owed some obligation to the graduates unable to find proper positions. The English universities had appointment secretaries. Harvard University had a similar official. UCB, she thought, should likewise give such a service to students. After she convinced UCB President [[Martin Kellogg]], her plan was accepted. She opened the UCB placement service in the president's office in South Hall on January 1, 1898, and continued to serve as the university’s Appointment Secretary for 40 years, placing countless university graduates as high-school teachers throughout the state. The Cheneys raised four sons, three of whom survived to adulthood. The eldest, Charles Henry Cheney (1884–1943), earned the first architectural degree awarded by UC before continuing his studies in Paris, eventually becoming a notable city planner and zoning expert. His son, Warren DeWitt Cheney (1907-1979), was a well-known sculptor and art teacher who took up psychology in midlife, founding the Transactional Analysis Journal.{{cite web| url=http://www.invaluable.com/artist/cheney-warren-dewitt-e1e1hbp3gx| title=Warren Dewitt Cheney (1907-1979)| work=Invaluable.com}} [[Sheldon Warren Cheney]] (1886–1980), entered his father’s real estate business before moving to Detroit, where he became a notable author and art critic. In 1916 he founded [[Theatre Arts Magazine]]. Marshall Chipman Cheney (1888–1972) became a physician. He did his residency at [[Massachusetts General Hospital]] in [[Boston]] before returning to Berkeley, where he practiced near the campus and at Cowell Memorial Hospital. He lived with his widowed mother at 2241 College Avenue until 1940. At the end of 1939, May Cheney sold her two campus houses to the university, and the family soon moved to 116 Tunnel Road. The two Cheney houses on campus were designated City of Berkeley Landmarks in 1990. Built in 1885, 2241 College Avenue is the second oldest surviving structure in the Berkeley Property Tract. May L. Cheney was the founder of the National Association of Appointment Secretaries (NAAS) now known as the [[American College Personnel Association]].
In choosing a permanent home we seek that place above all others which promises abundance of life, stimulus, interests that postpone as long as possible the inevitable apathy of old age. Where do we find this precious boon more abundantly than in Berkeley?May L. Cheney, ''Berkeley Reporter'', December 1906
==Cheney unhurt in campus shooting== On August 4, 1919, Cheney was shot at by Roger Sprague, a chemistry assistant who was despondent at not being recommended for further advancement. She escaped unhurt.{{cite news| url=http://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SU19190805.2.6| title=Refused Position, Man Attempts Life Of Two Professors| work=[[The Sacramento Union]], Volume 209, Number 36 (Sacramento, California)| date=5 August 1919| page=1| accessdate=4 April 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://berkeleyheritage.com/berkeley_landmarks/cheney.html 2241 College Avenue - Historic Structure Report] detailed accounts regarding May L. Cheney's College Avenue home in Berkeley which was later acquired by UC Berkeley. Its uses after purchase are also included, as well as a history of May and her family {{DEFAULTSORT:Cheney, May L.}} [[Category:American educators]] [[Category:Educational administration]] [[Category:Educational organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:1862 births]] [[Category:1942 deaths]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley alumni]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley staff]]

{{Infobox award | name = Petrochemical Heritage Award | current_awards = | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | description = "to recognize individuals who made outstanding contributions to the petrochemical community" | presenter = [[Founders Club]], [[Science History Institute]] | sponsor = | host = | date = {{Start date|1997}} | location = | country = | reward = | year = | year2 = | holder = | website = | network = | runtime = | ratings = | previous = | main = | next = }}
The '''Petrochemical Heritage Award''' was established in 1997, "to recognize individuals who made outstanding contributions to the [[petrochemical industry|petrochemical community]]."<ref name="Quote">{{cite news|title=Chemical Heritage Foundation to present Petrochemical Heritage Award to Harold Sorgenti|url=http://www3.scienceblog.com/community/older/2002/G/20021571.html|accessdate=24 March 2018|work=Science Blog|date=November 2002}}</ref> The award is intended to inspire achievement and to promote public understanding. The award winner is chosen annually by the Founders Club and the [[Science History Institute]] (formerly the Chemical Heritage Foundation). The award is traditionally presented at the [[International Petrochemical Conference]] hosted by the [[American Fuel and Petrochemical Manufacturers]] (AFPM), formerly known as NPRA, the National Petrochemical & Refiners Association.<ref name="Award">{{cite web|title=Petrochemical Heritage Award|url=https://www.sciencehistory.org/petrochemical-heritage-award|website=Science History Institute|accessdate=24 March 2018}}</ref>
==Recipients== The following people have received the Petrochemical Heritage Award:<ref name="Award"/>
* 2018, [[Gary K. Adams]], former president, CEO, and chair of the board of Chemical Market Associates<ref name="Award"/> * 2017, [[David N. Weidman]], retired chair and CEO of [[Celanese|Celanese Corporation]]<ref name="Award"/><ref name="Weidman">{{cite web|title=2017 Petrochemical Award Honoree Dave Weidman|url=http://thefoundersclub.net/page-1756507|website=The Founders Club|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> * 2016, [[Stephen D. Pryor]], retired president of ExxonMobil Chemical Company<ref name="Founders">{{cite web|title=Stephen D. Pryor|url=http://thefoundersclub.net/Petrochemical-Heritage-Award-Past-Recipients|website=The Founders Club|accessdate=18 May 2016}}</ref> * 2015, [[James L. Gallogly]], former chief executive officer of [[LyondellBasell]]<ref name=Gallogly2015>{{cite web|title=Former LyondellBasell CEO to Receive 2015 Petrochemical Heritage Award|url=http://www.chemheritage.org/about/news-and-press/press-releases/2015-02-23-former-lyondellbasell-ceo-to-receive-2015-petrochemical-heritage-award.aspx|website=Chemical Heritage Foundation|accessdate=February 23, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160712192938/http://www.chemheritage.org/about/news-and-press/press-releases/2015-02-23-former-lyondellbasell-ceo-to-receive-2015-petrochemical-heritage-award.aspx|archivedate=12 July 2016|df=}}</ref> * 2014, [[Frank Popoff]], retired chairman and chief executive officer of the [[Dow Chemical Company]]<ref name=Midland2014>{{cite news|title=Popoff receives Petrochemical Heritage Award|url=http://www.ourmidland.com/news/popoff-receives-petrochemical-heritage-award/article_df5c9fa6-cedd-11e3-b569-0019bb2963f4.html|accessdate=28 October 2014|work=Midland Daily News|date=April 28, 2014}}</ref> * 2013, [[Jim Ratcliffe]], [[Ineos|INEOS]] Founder and CEO<ref name=Founders2013>{{cite web|title=INEOS Founder and CEO will receive coveted Petrochemical Heritage Award during the IPC 2013 Opening Session in San Antonio, Texas, March 25th|url=http://thefoundersclub.camp9.org/page-1517469|website=The Founders Club|accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref> * 2012, [[Marvin O. Schlanger]], chairman of the supervisory board of [[LyondellBasell|LyondellBasell Industries]]<ref name=Award2012>{{cite web|title=Marvin O. Schlanger to Receive 2012 Petrochemical Heritage Award|url=http://www.chemheritage.org/about/news-and-press/press-releases/2012-03-22-petro-heritage-award.aspx|publisher=Chemical Heritage Foundation|accessdate=March 22, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160712194209/http://www.chemheritage.org/about/news-and-press/press-releases/2012-03-22-petro-heritage-award.aspx|archivedate=12 July 2016|df=}}</ref><ref name=IHS2012>{{cite news|last1=Westervelt|first1=Robert|title=IPC 2012: Schlanger Receives Petrochemical Heritage Award|url=http://www.chemweek.com/chem_ideas/Guest-Author/IPC-2012-Schlanger-Receives-Petrochemical-Heritage-Award_42465.html|accessdate=28 October 2014|work=IHS Chemical Week|date=April 17, 2012}}</ref> * 2011, [[Raj Gupta]], former chairman and CEO of [[Rohm and Haas]]<ref name=Award2011>{{cite web|title=Raj L. Gupta to Receive 2011 Petrochemical Heritage Award|url=http://www.chemheritage.org/about/news-and-press/press-releases/2011-03-22-petro-heritage-award.aspx|website=Chemical Heritage Foundation|accessdate=28 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160712194501/http://www.chemheritage.org/about/news-and-press/press-releases/2011-03-22-petro-heritage-award.aspx|archivedate=12 July 2016|df=}}</ref> * 2010, [[Hiromasa Yonekura]], chairman of the [[Sumitomo Chemical|Sumitomo Chemical Company]]<ref name=CHM2010>{{cite journal|title=Hiromasa Yonekura|journal=Chemical Heritage Magazine|date=Spring 2010|volume=28|issue=1|page=12}}</ref> * 2009, [[Mohamed Al-Mady]], vice chairman and CEO of the [[SABIC|Saudi Basic Industries Corporation]] (SABIC)<ref name=Award2009>{{cite news|title=Sabic's Al-Mady Receives Petrochemical Heritage Award|url=http://www.chemweek.com/people_and_business/people_executives/17923.html|accessdate=28 October 2014|work=IHS Chemical Week|date=March 31, 2009}}</ref> * 2008, [[Peter R. Huntsman]], president and CEO of the [[Huntsman Corporation]]<ref name=CAEN2008/> * 2008, [[Dave C. Duncan]], chairman, [[Enterprise Products|Enterprise Products Partners]]<ref name=Award2007>{{cite news|title=Duncan Wins Petrochemical Heritage Award|url=http://aimediaserver4.com/chemweek/pdf/NPRA07.pdf|page=1|accessdate=28 October 2014|work=IHS Chemical Week|date=March 27, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141029153655/http://aimediaserver4.com/chemweek/pdf/NPRA07.pdf|archivedate=29 October 2014|df=}}</ref> * 2006, [[J. Virgil Waggoner]], former president and CEO of [[Sterling Chemicals]]<ref name=CAEN2006>{{cite journal|title=J. Virgil Waggoner Wins Petrochemical Heritage Award|journal=Chemical & Engineering News|date=February 13, 2006|volume=84|issue=7|url=http://pubs.acs.org/subscribe/journals/cen/84/i07/toc/toc_i07.html |accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=WaggonerEureka>{{cite news|last1=Gussman|first1=Neil|title=Chemical Heritage Foundation to present Petrochemical Heritage Award to J. Virgil Waggoner|url=http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2005-12/chf-chf122905.php|accessdate=29 October 2014|agency=EurekaAlert|date=29 December 2005}}</ref> * 2005, [[Ting Tsung Chao]], founder of the [[Westlake Chemical|Westlake Chemical Corporation]]<ref name=CAEN2005>{{cite journal|title=Petrochemical Execs Gather in Texas|last=Tullo|first=Alex|journal=Chemical & Engineering News|date=April 18, 2005|volume=83|issue=16|url=http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/cen-v083n016.p019|accessdate=28 October 2014|doi=10.1021/cen-v083n016.p019}}</ref><ref name=Chao2008>{{cite news|last1=Abram|first1=Lynwood|title=Chao, pioneered petrochemical ventures around the world|url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-deaths/article/Chao-pioneered-petrochemical-ventures-around-the-1785030.php|accessdate=28 October 2014|work=Houston Chronicle|date=March 16, 2008}}</ref> * 2004, [[William A. McMinn, Jr.]], former president of [[Cain Chemical]]<ref name=Award2004>{{cite news|title=Petrochemical Heritage Award to William A. McMinn, Jr.|url=http://psychcentral.com/news/archives/2004-01/chf-pha010504.html|accessdate=28 October 2014|work=PsychCentral|date=5 January 2004}}</ref> * 2003, [[Harold Sorgenti]], former president and chief executive officer of [[ARCO|ARCO Chemical Company]]<ref name=Sorgenti>{{cite news|last1=Gussman|first1=Neil|title=Chemical Heritage Foundation to present Petrochemical Heritage Award to Harold Sorgenti|url=http://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2002-11/chf-chf111702.php|accessdate=28 October 2014|work=EurekaAlert|date=November 12, 2002}}</ref> * 2002, [[Herbert D. "Ted" Doan]], former chairman and CEO of the [[Dow Chemical Company]]<ref name=CAEN2002>{{cite journal|title=Awards|journal=Chemical & Engineering News|date=March 18, 2002|volume=80|issue=11|url=http://pubs.acs.org/doi/pdf/10.1021/cen-v080n011.p047|accessdate=28 October 2014|doi=10.1021/cen-v080n011.p047|pages=47}}</ref> * 2001, [[Jon Huntsman, Sr.|Jon M. Huntsman]], founder of [[Huntsman Corporation]]<ref name=CAEN2001>{{cite journal|title=2001 ACS National Award Winners|journal=Chemical & Engineering News|date=January 29, 2001|volume=79|issue=5|url=http://cen.acs.org/articles/79/i5/html/7905awar.html|accessdate=28 October 2014}}</ref> * 2000, [[Ralph Landau]], cofounder of Scientific Design Group and Halcon.<ref name=CAEN2000>{{cite journal|title=Petrochemical Heritage Award Will Go To Ralph Landau|journal=Chemical & Engineering News|date=March 20, 2000|volume=78|issue=12|url=http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/cen-v078n012.p051|accessdate=28 October 2014|doi=10.1021/cen-v078n012.p051|pages=51–53}}</ref> * 1999, [[John R. Hall (chemist)|John R. Files]], founder and chairman of the [[Merichem Company]]<ref name=Merichem>{{cite journal|title=Merichem chairman awarded|work=Chemical Market Reporter|volume=253|issue= 4|page=41|date=26 January 1998}}</ref> * 1997, [[Gordon Cain]], chemical engineer and entrepreneur<ref name="Award"/>

{{Crystallization}} '''Shaping processes in crystal growth''' are a collection of techniques for growing bulk [[crystals]] of a defined shape from a melt, usually by constraining the shape of the liquid [[meniscus (liquid)|meniscus]] by means of a mechanical shaper. Crystals are commonly grown as fibers, solid cylinders, hollow cylinders (or tubes), and sheets (or plates). More complex shapes such as tubes with a complex cross section, and domes have also been produced.<ref name="springer">Dobrovinskaya, Elena R., Leonid A. Lytvynov, and Valerian Pishchik. Sapphire: material, manufacturing, applications. Springer Science & Business Media, 2009. {{ISBN|0387856943}}</ref> Using a shaping process can produce a [[near net shape]] crystal and reduce the manufacturing cost for crystals which are composed of very expensive or difficult to machine materials.
== List of shaping processes == * Edge-defined film-fed growth (EFG) * Horizontal ribbon growth (HRG) * [[Micro-pulling-down]] (µ-PD) * Stepanov technique * [[String ribbon]]
== Edge-defined film-fed growth == '''Edge-defined film-fed growth''' or '''EFG''' was developed for [[sapphire#synthetic sapphire|sapphire]] growth in the late 1960s by Harold LaBelle and A. Mlavsky at Tyco Industries.<ref name="RobichaudHarris2009">{{cite journal|last1=Robichaud|first1=Joseph L.|last2=Harris|first2=Daniel C.|last3=Goodman|first3=William A.|title=A century of sapphire crystal growth: origin of the EFG method|volume=7425|year=2009|pages=74250P|issn=0277786X|doi=10.1117/12.824452}}</ref> A shaper (also referred to as a die) having dimensions approximately equal to the crystal to be grown rests above the surface of the melt which is contained in a [[crucible]]. [[Capillary action]] feeds liquid material to a slit at the center of the shaper. When a [[seed crystal]] is touched to the liquid film and raised upwards, a [[single crystal]] forms at the [[interface (matter)|interface]] between the solid seed and the liquid film. By continuing to pull the seed upwards, the crystal expands as a liquid film forms between the crystal and the top surface of the shaper. When the film reaches the edges of the shaper, the final crystal shape matches that of the shaper.
The exact dimensions of the crystal will deviate from the dimensions of the shaper because every material has a characteristic '''growth angle''', the angle formed at the triple interface between the solid crystal, liquid film, and the atmosphere.<ref name="Duffar">{{cite book|last1=Duffar|first1=Thierry|editor1-last=Rudolph|editor1-first=Peter|title=Handbook of Crystal Growth Vol. IIB|date=2015|publisher=Elsevier B.V.|pages=758-789|edition=2nd|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/B978-0-444-63303-3.00019-5|chapter=Capillarity and Shape Stability in Crystal Growth from the Melt}}</ref> Because of the growth angle, varying the height of the meniscus (i.e. the thickness of the liquid film) will change the dimensions of the crystal. The meniscus height is affected by pulling speed and crystallization rate. The crystallization rate depends on the temperature gradient above the shaper, which is determined by the configuration of the hot-zone of the crystal growth [[vacuum furnace|furnace]], and the [[electric power|power]] applied to the heating elements during growth. The difference in [[thermal expansion]] coefficients between the shaper material and the crystal material can also cause appreciable size differences between the shaper and the crystal at room temperature for crystals grown at high temperatures.
The shaper material should be non-reactive with both the melt and growth atmosphere, and should be [[wetting|wet]] by the melt.<ref name="Surek">{{cite journal|last1=Surek|first1=T.|last2=Coriell|first2=S.R.|last3=Chalmers|first3=B.|title=The growth of shaped crystals from the melt|journal=Journal of Crystal Growth|volume=50|issue=1|year=1980|pages=21–32|issn=00220248|doi=10.1016/0022-0248(80)90227-4}}</ref>
It is possible to grow multiple crystals from a single crucible using the EFG technique, for example by growing many parallel sheets.
=== Applications ===
'''Sapphire''': EFG is used to grow large plates of [[sapphire]], primarily for use as robust [[infrared]] windows for [[arms industry|defense]] and other applications. Windows about 7 mm thick x 300  mm wide x 500 mm long are produced.<ref>{{cite web|title=CLASS Sapphire Sheets|url=https://www.crystals.saint-gobain.com/products/sapphire-large-sheets-class|website=Saint-Gobain|accessdate=25 January 2018}}</ref> The shaper is typically made from [[molybdenum]].
'''Silicon:''' EFG was used in the 2000s by [[Schott AG#Schott Solar|Schott Solar]] to produce [[silicon]] sheets for [[solar photovoltaic]] panels, by pulling a thin-walled (~250-300 μm) octagon with faces 12.5 cm on a side and diameter about 38 cm, about 5-6 m long.<ref name="MackintoshSeidl2006">{{cite journal|last1=Mackintosh|first1=B|last2=Seidl|first2=A|last3=Ouellette|first3=M|last4=Bathey|first4=B|last5=Yates|first5=D|last6=Kelejs|first6=J|title=Large silicon crystal hollow-tube growth by the edge-defined film-fed growth (EFG) method|journal=Journal of Crystal Growth|date=25 January 2006|volume=287|issue=2|pages=428-432|doi=10.1016/j.jcrysgro.2005.11.058}}</ref> The shaper is typically made from [[graphite]].
'''Other oxides''': Many high melting-point oxides have been grown by EFG, among them [[Gallium(III) oxide|Ga<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>]], [[Lithium niobate|LiNbO<sub>3</sub>]], and Nd<sup>3+</sup>:(Lu<sub>x</sub>Gd<sub>1−x</sub>)<sub>3</sub>Ga<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub> (Nd:LGGG).<ref name="MuJia2017">{{cite journal|last1=Mu|first1=Wenxiang|last2=Jia|first2=Zhitai|last3=Yin|first3=Yanru|last4=Hu|first4=Qiangqiang|last5=Li|first5=Yang|last6=Tao|first6=Xutang|title=Growth of homogeneous Nd:LGGG single crystal plates by edge-defined film-fed growth method|journal=Journal of Crystal Growth|volume=478|year=2017|pages=17–21|issn=00220248|doi=10.1016/j.jcrysgro.2017.08.007}}</ref> Often an [[iridium]] shaper is used.
== Horizontal ribbon growth == '''Horizontal ribbon growth''' or '''HRG''' is a method developed for [[silicon]] by which a thin crystalline sheet is pulled horizontally from the top of a crucible. The melt level must be constantly replenished in order to keep the surface of the melt at the same height as the edge of the crucible from which the sheet is being pulled. By blowing a cooling gas at the surface of the growing sheet, very high growth rates (>400 mm/min) can be achieved. <ref name="Kudo1980">{{cite journal|last1=Kudo|first1=B.|title=Improvements in the Horizontal Ribbon Growth technique for single crystal silicon|journal=Journal of Crystal Growth|date=1980|volume=50|issue=1|pages=247-259|doi=10.1016/0022-0248(80)90248-1}}</ref> The method relies on the solid crystal floating on the surface of the melt, which works because solid silicon is less dense than liquid silicon.
== Micro-pulling-down == :{{main|Micro-pulling-down}}
The '''micro-pulling-down''' or '''µ-PD''' technique uses a small round opening in the bottom of the crucible to pull a crystalline fiber downward. Hundreds of different crystalline materials have been grown by this technique.
A variation called '''pendant drop growth''' or '''PDG''' uses a slot in the bottom of the crucible to produce crystalline sheets in a similar manner.<ref name="Duffar" />
== Stepanov technique == The '''Stepanov technique''' was developed by A.V. Stepanov in the Soviet Union after 1950.<ref name="springer" /> The method involves pulling a crystal vertically through a shaper located at the surface of the melt. The shaper is not necessarily fed by a capillary channel as in EFG.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Tatartchenko|first1=Vitali|editor1-last=Dhanaraj|editor1-first=Govindhan|editor2-last=et. al.|title=Springer Handbook of Crystal Growth|date=2010|publisher=Springer|pages=537-541|chapter=Shaped Crystal Growth: TPS Brief History}}</ref> The shaper material may be [[wetting|wetted]] or non-wetted by the melt, as opposed to EFG where the shaper material is wetted.<ref name="Surek" /> The technique has been used to grow metal, semiconductor, and oxide crystals.
[[Czochralski]] growth using a floating shaper known as a "coracle" was done for some [[III-V semiconductors]] prior to the development of advanced control-systems for diameter control.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Winkler|first1=Jan|last2=Neubert|first2=Michael|editor1-last=Rudolph|editor1-first=Peter|title=Handbook of Crystal Growth|date=2015|publisher=Elsevier B.V.|page=1153|edition=2nd|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/B978-0-444-63303-3.00028-6|chapter=Automation of Crystal Growth from Melt}}</ref>
== String ribbon == :{{main|String ribbon}}
The '''string ribbon''' method, also known as '''dendritic web''' or '''edge-supported pulling''', has been used to grow semiconductor sheets including [[indium antimonide]], [[gallium arsenide]], [[germanium]], and silicon.<ref name="SeidenstickerHopkins1980">{{cite journal|last1=Seidensticker|first1=R.G.|last2=Hopkins|first2=R.H.|title=Silicon ribbon growth by the dendritic web process|journal=Journal of Crystal Growth|volume=50|issue=1|year=1980|pages=221–235|issn=00220248|doi=10.1016/0022-0248(80)90246-8}}</ref> A seed crystal with the width and thickness matching the sheet to be grown is dipped into the top surface of the melt. Strings of a suitable material are fixed to the vertical edges of the seed and extend down through holes in the bottom of the crucible to a spool. As the seed is raised, string is continuously fed through the melt and a liquid film forms between the seed, the strings, and the melt. The film crystallizes to the seed, forming a sheet or ribbon.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Shaping processes in crystal growth}}
[[Category:Semiconductor growth]] [[Category:Industrial processes]] [[Category:Crystals]]
