{{refimprove|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox State Representative |image= |image size= |caption= |office= [[Louisiana House of Representatives|Louisiana State Representative
for Grant Parish]] |term_start=1904 |term_end=1908 |preceded=C. M. Brannon |succeeded=C. W. Payne |birth_name=Stephen Roland Lee |birth_place=[[Perry County, Mississippi|Perry County]], [[Mississippi]], USA |birth_date={{birth date|1859|2|8}} |death_place=[[Alexandria, Louisiana|Alexandria]], [[Rapides Parish, Louisiana|Rapides Parish]]
[[Louisiana]] |death_date={{death date and age|1929|2|13|1859|2|8}} |resting_place=Greenwood Memorial Park in [[Pineville, Louisiana|Pineville]], Louisiana |party=[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] |religion= |residence=(1) [[Pollock, Louisiana|Pollock]], [[Grant Parish, Louisiana|Grant Parish]]
(2) Alexandria, Louisiana |spouse=Cornelia Nugent Lee (married 1884–1929, his death) |children=Seven children |relations=[[Huey Long|Huey P. Long, Jr.]] (cousin by marriage)
[[James Eubank]] (grandson) |occupation=[[Lumber]]man |alma_mater= |footnotes= }} '''Stephen Roland Lee, Sr.''', known as '''Swords R. Lee''' (February 8, 1859 – February 13, 1929), was a wealthy [[lumber]]man from [[Pollock, Louisiana|Pollock]] and then [[Alexandria, Louisiana|Alexandria]], [[Louisiana]], who served as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] member of the [[Louisiana House of Representatives]] for his adopted [[Grant Parish, Louisiana|Grant Parish]] from 1904 to 1908. His term corresponded with the administration of [[governor of Louisiana|Governor]] [[Newton C. Blanchard]].{{cite web|url=http://house.louisiana.gov/H_PDFdocs/HouseMembership_History_CURRENT.pdf|title=Membership in the Louisiana House of Representatives, 1812-2016: Grant Parish|publisher=house.louisiana.gov|accessdate=May 23, 2015}} ==Biography== One of eight children of Stephen Lee, Sr., and the former Rebecca Grantham, Lee was born two years before the start of the [[American Civil War]] in [[Perry County, Mississippi|Perry County]] in southeastern [[Mississippi]]. He was a lineal descendant of [[Light Horse Harry Lee]] of [[Virginia (U.S. state)|Virginia]], the father of [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] [[General]] [[Robert E. Lee]]. His grandfather, Elijah Lee of [[North Carolina]], fought in the 1815 [[Battle of New Orleans]] under General [[Andrew Jackson]]. Lee's middle was derived from his paternal grandmother, Martha Roland. The Lees left Perry County when he was twelve years of age. He was educated in the [[State school|public schools]] of Grant Parish; after reaching adulthood, he taught school for a number of years.{{cite web|url=http://files.usgwarchives.net/la/winn/obits/l/leesr229.txt|title=Col. Stephen R. Lee of Alexandria Dies at His Home Feb. 13: Industrial and Political Leader, Descendant of Famous Lees|date=February 22, 1929|work=Winnfield News-American |location=[[Winnfield, Louisiana]]|accessdate=May 23, 2015}} Lee was the president and general manager of the Lee Lumber Company, which operated a large [[sawmill]] at [[Tioga, Louisiana|Tioga]] in northwestern [[Rapides Parish, Louisiana|Rapides Parish]]. The company closed c. 1917 after the nearby timber was exhausted. He was the Grant Parish [[Assessor (property)|assessor]] during the 1890s, having been appointed to the since elected position by then Governor [[Murphy J. Foster, Sr.]] After his legislative term ended, he relocated to Alexandria. He had a large political following and worked in 1928 for the successful election of [[Louisiana Public Service Commission]]er [[Huey Long|Huey Pierce Long, Jr.]], as the Louisiana governor. Lee was a cousin by marriage of Huey Long.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_0CKVuAldzEC&pg=PA284|title=Kingfish: The Reign of Huey P. Long|author=Richard White|page=284|publisher=Random House|location=[[New York City]]|isbn=0-8129-7383-6|date=2006|accessdate=May 23, 2015}} On November 12, 1884, Lee married Martha Cornelia Nugent (1862-1933), a daughter of Matthew and Julie Ann Mackie Nugent, pioneer Grant Parish settlers. Lee died of an illness of several months at his Alexandria home at the intersection of Fourth and St. James streets five days after his seventieth birthday. He was survived by his widow and four children, Maude Lee Eubank (1885-1958) and husband Benjamin Franklin Eubank (1882-1962), J. H. Lee, and Ethel Lee Jarrell (1896-1967) and husband Marion Fahy Jarrell (1897-1977), all of Alexandria, and Mrs. S. J. Rogers of [[Monroe, Louisiana|Monroe]] in [[Ouachita Parish, Louisiana|Ouachita Parish]] in northeast Louisiana. Three other Lee children had died prior to their father, Florence, Lucille, and Samuel Patterson Lee. He had two surviving grandsons, one of whom, [[James Eubank]] served briefly in the Louisiana House in 1952, during which time he was a floor leader for Governor [[Robert F. Kennon]]. Representative Eubank died of a [[Myocardial infarction|heart attack]] in Alexandria at the age of thirty-seven.{{cite news|title=James Rowland Eubank|work=[[The Advocate (Louisiana)|The Baton Rouge Morning Advocate]]|date=November 10, 1952}} Lee is interred with other family members at Greenwood Memorial Park in [[Pineville, Louisiana|Pineville]]. Both [[Methodist]] and [[Southern Baptist]] pastors officiated at his funeral, with [[Masonic lodge]] graveside rites following. {{Portalbar|Mississippi|Louisiana|Education|Business and Economics|Politics|Christianity}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{S-start}} {{s-par|us-la-hs}} {{succession box | before=C. M. Brannon| title=[[Louisiana House of Representatives|Louisiana State Representative for Grant Parish]] Stephen Roland "Swords" Lee, Jr. |years=1904–1908| after=C. W. Payne}} {{S-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lee, Swords}} [[Category:1859 births]] [[Category:1929 deaths]] [[Category:Lee family of Virginia]] [[Category:Long family]] [[Category:People from Perry County, Mississippi]] [[Category:People from Pollock, Louisiana]] [[Category:American schoolteachers]] [[Category:People from Alexandria, Louisiana]] [[Category:Louisiana Democrats]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Louisiana]] [[Category:Businesspeople in timber]] [[Category:Parish officials in Louisiana]] [[Category:Members of the Louisiana House of Representatives]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox Australian place | type = suburb | name = Sydney central business district | city = Sydney | state = nsw | image =Sydney City Business District.jpg | caption = Sydney central business district | coordinates = {{coord|33|52|5|S|151|12|44|E|display=inline,title}} | pop = 17252 |pop_year = 2016 |pop_footnotes ={{Census 2016 AUS|id=SSC13715 |name=Sydney (State Suburb) |accessdate=28 June 2017 |quick=on}} | est = | postcode = 2000 | area = 2.8 | dist1 = | dir1 = | location1 = | lga = [[City of Sydney]] | stategov = [[Electoral district of Sydney|Sydney]] | fedgov = [[Division of Sydney|Sydney]] | near-n = [[Millers Point, New South Wales|Millers Point]]
[[The Rocks, New South Wales|The Rocks]] | near-ne = ''[[Port Jackson]]'' | near-e = [[Woolloomooloo]]
[[Darlinghurst, New South Wales|Darlinghurst]] | near-se = [[Surry Hills, New South Wales|Surry Hills]] | near-s = [[Haymarket, New South Wales|Haymarket]]
[[Ultimo, New South Wales|Ultimo]] | near-sw = [[Ultimo, New South Wales|Ultimo]] | near-w = [[Pyrmont, New South Wales|Pyrmont]] | near-nw = [[Barangaroo, New South Wales|Barangaroo]] }} The '''Sydney central business district''' (also '''Sydney CBD''', and often referred to simply as "'''Town'''" or "'''the City'''") is the main [[Central business district|commercial centre]] of [[Sydney]], the state capital of [[New South Wales]] and the most populous city in [[Australia]]. It extends southwards for about {{convert|3|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} from [[Sydney Cove]], the point of first European settlement in which the [[Regions of Sydney|Sydney region]] was initially established. Due to its pivotal role in Australia's early history, it is one of the oldest established areas in the country. Geographically, its north–south axis runs from [[Circular Quay]] in the north to [[Central railway station, Sydney|Central railway station]] in the south. Its east–west axis runs from a chain of parkland that includes [[Hyde Park, Sydney|Hyde Park]], [[The Domain, Sydney|The Domain]], [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Sydney|Royal Botanic Gardens]] and [[Farm Cove, New South Wales|Farm Cove]] on [[Port Jackson|Sydney Harbour]] in the east; to [[Darling Harbour]] and the [[Western Distributor (Sydney)|Western Distributor]] in the west. At the 2016 Australian Census, the CBD recorded a population of 17,252. "Sydney CBD" is very occasionally used to refer not only to the CBD proper, but also its nearby inner suburbs such as [[Pyrmont, New South Wales|Pyrmont]], [[Haymarket, New South Wales|Haymarket]], [[Ultimo, New South Wales|Ultimo]] and [[Woolloomooloo, New South Wales|Woolloomooloo]]. The Sydney CBD is Australia's main financial and economic centre, as well as a leading hub of economic activity for the Asia-Pacific region. The city centre employs approximately 13% of the Sydney region's workforce. Based on industry mix and relative occupational wage levels it is estimated that economic activity ( GDP ) generated in the city in 2015/16 was approximately $118 billion.{{Cite web|url=http://www.taxpayer.com.au/News/28447/Australia’s_economic_activity_heavily_concentrated_in_Sydney_and_Melbourne|title=Australia's economic activity heavily concentrated in Sydney and Melbourne|publisher=taxpayer.com.au|date=21 August 2014|accessdate=31 March 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150401184658/http://www.taxpayer.com.au/News/28447/Australia%E2%80%99s_economic_activity_heavily_concentrated_in_Sydney_and_Melbourne#|archive-date=1 April 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} Culturally, the city centre is Sydney's focal point for [[nightlife]] and entertainment. It is also home to some of the city's most significant [[List of tallest buildings in Sydney|buildings and structures]]. == Geography == {{Main|Geography of Sydney}} The Sydney CBD is an area of very densely concentrated skyscrapers and other buildings, interspersed by several parks such as [[Hyde Park, Sydney|Hyde Park]], [[The Domain, Sydney|The Domain]], [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Sydney|Royal Botanic Gardens]] and [[Wynyard Park, Sydney|Wynyard Park]]. [[George Street, Sydney|George Street]] is the Sydney CBD's main north–south thoroughfare. The streets run on a slightly warped grid pattern in the southern CBD, but in the older northern CBD the streets form several intersecting grids, reflecting their placement in relation to the prevailing breeze and orientation to Circular Quay in early settlement. The CBD runs along two ridge lines below Macquarie Street and York Streets. Between these ridges is Pitt Street, running close to the course of the original [[Tank Stream]] (now tunnelled). [[Bridge Street, Sydney|Bridge Street]], took its name from the bridge running east–west that once crossed this stream. [[Pitt Street, Sydney|Pitt Street]] is the retail heart of the city which includes the [[Pitt Street Mall]] and the [[Sydney Tower]]. [[Macquarie Street, Sydney|Macquarie Street]] is a historic precinct that houses such buildings as the State [[Parliament House, Sydney|Parliament House]] and the [[Supreme Court of New South Wales]]. [[File:Sydney Town Hall - Panorama.jpg|thumb|centre|500px|Panoramic view of the [[Sydney Town Hall]]]] == History == {{expand section|date=August 2018}} In the midst of World War 1, on Valentine's day, riots racked the CBD, in what has come to be known as the Central Station Riots of 1916. A substantial segment of the violence was concentrated in the Central area. These riots involved five thousand military recruits who refused to comply with extraneous parade orders. During the riots they caused significant damage to buildings. People with "foreign" names were especially targeted. The recruits clashed with soldiers, resulting in the death of Private Ernest William Keefe. A number of eight people sustained injuries. Because this incident occurred in the middle of the Great War the state discouraged media coverage. Only a fifth of the rioters were court-marshalled. These riots spurred the introduction of lockout laws for pubs after 6pm. This law was only lifted in 1955.{{cite web |title=The Central Station Riots of 1916 |url=http://www.historyofsydney.com.au/the-central-station-riots-of-1916/ |website=History of Sydney}} == Heritage listings == Sydney CBD has many heritage-listed buildings including: ** 150-152 Elizabeth Street: [[Cyprus Hellene Club - Australian Hall]]{{cite AHD|105937|Cyprus Hellene Club - Australian Hall|fn=1/12/036/0589|accessdate=13 October 2018}} == Governance == Administratively, the Sydney CBD falls under the authority of the [[Local government in Australia|local government area]] of the [[City of Sydney]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/|title=Home|publisher=City of Sydney|accessdate=6 April 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110219055647/http://www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/#|archive-date=19 February 2011|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} The [[Government of New South Wales|New South Wales state government]] also has authority over some aspects of the CBD, in particular through the [[Sydney Harbour Foreshore Authority]]. [[Independent (politics)|Independent]] [[Alex Greenwich]] has represented the Sydney seat since the [[Sydney state by-election, 2012|2012 by-election]], triggered by the resignation of previous independent [[Clover Moore]], who was the [[Lord Mayor of Sydney]], due to introduced state laws preventing dual membership of state parliament and local council. == Commercial area == The Sydney CBD is home to some of the largest Australian companies, as well as serving as an Asia-Pacific headquarters for many large international companies. The financial services industry in particular occupies much of the available office space, with companies such as the [[Westpac]], [[Commonwealth Bank|Commonwealth Bank of Australia]], [[Citibank]], [[Deutsche Bank]], [[Macquarie Bank]], [[AMP Limited]], [[Insurance Australia Group]], AON, Marsh, Allianz, [[HSBC]], [[AXA]], [[ABN Amro]],"[https://www.abnamro.com/en/careers/international/australia/index.html Australia] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170216141914/https://www.abnamro.com/en/careers/international/australia/index.html# |date=16 February 2017 }}." ABN Amro. Retrieved 15 February 2017., [[Royal Bank of Canada|RBC]] and [[Bloomsbury Publishing]] all having offices."[http://www.bloomsbury.com/uk/company/contact-us/ Contact Us] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013220523/http://www.bloomsbury.com/uk/company/contact-us/# |date=13 October 2012 }}." [[Bloomsbury Publishing]]. Retrieved 14 October 2012. "Bloomsbury Publishing Pty Ltd. Level 14 309 Kent St Sydney NSW 2000 Australia" === Church Hill === ''Church Hill'' is a northerly district in the Central Business district of [[Sydney]], Australia.{{Cite web|url=http://www.visitsydneyaustralia.com.au/church-hill.html|title=Church Hill|access-date=10 August 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180810042202/http://www.visitsydneyaustralia.com.au/church-hill.html#|archive-date=10 August 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} It is so named because the earliest churches in Australia were formed on this site, including St Patrick's (Roman Catholic),{{Cite web|url=http://stpatschurchhill.org/about-st-patricks-church-hill-sydney/|title=About St Patrick's Church Hill|access-date=10 August 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180810072550/http://stpatschurchhill.org/about-st-patricks-church-hill-sydney/#|archive-date=10 August 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} St Philip's (Anglican){{Cite web|url=http://www.churchhillanglican.com/|title=St Philip's / Church Hill|access-date=10 August 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180810042319/http://www.churchhillanglican.com/#|archive-date=10 August 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} and [[Scots Church, Sydney|Scots Church]] (Presbyterian){{Cite web|url=http://scotschurchsydney.org/|title=Scots Church Sydney|access-date=10 August 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180809101446/http://scotschurchsydney.org/#|archive-date=9 August 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} The significance of Church Hill dates back to the time of Governor [[Arthur Phillip]], who mandated compulsory Sunday church attendance for all convicts, until they rebelled and burned down the area’s first church in 1798.{{Cite web|url=http://www.visitsydneyaustralia.com.au/church-hill.html|title=Church Hill|access-date=10 August 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180810042202/http://www.visitsydneyaustralia.com.au/church-hill.html#|archive-date=10 August 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} The area gained greater prominence as Church Hill on Wednesday 1 October 1800, when incoming Governor [[Philip Gidley King]] had the foundation stone laid for St Philip’s Church, which subsequently he proclaimed one of Australia’s first two parishes in 1802 (the other being St John’s in [[Parramatta]]).{{Cite web|url=http://www.visitsydneyaustralia.com.au/church-hill.html|title=Church Hill|access-date=10 August 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180810042202/http://www.visitsydneyaustralia.com.au/church-hill.html#|archive-date=10 August 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} The site where St Patrick’s Church currently stands is where the [[Roman Catholic]] [[Eucharist]] was first preserved in Australia, in May 1818. Celebrations for the bicentenary of this occasion were held in St Patrick’s Church on Sunday 6 May 2018.{{Cite web|url=https://www.catholicweekly.com.au/200-years-blessed-sacrament-celebrated-birthplace-church-australia/|title=200 years of the Blessed Sacrament celebrated at the “birthplace” of the Church in Australia|access-date=10 August 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180810061119/https://www.catholicweekly.com.au/200-years-blessed-sacrament-celebrated-birthplace-church-australia/#|archive-date=10 August 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} A proposed stop on the tram network under construction on George Street may be named Church Hill. ==Transport== [[File:2015-04-02 George Street, Sydney.jpg|thumb|[[George Street, Sydney|George Street]], the main CBD thoroughfare]] {{Main|Public transport in Sydney}} Sydney's CBD is serviced by [[commuter rail]], [[light rail]], [[buses]] and [[Sydney Ferries|ferry]] transport. In addition, an underground [[rapid transit]] system known as the [[Sydney Metro]] is being developed: its first stage will link the [[Sydney Metro Northwest|central business district to the North Western suburbs]] of Sydney{{cite web|title=Funding secured: Sydney Metro to be a reality|url=http://www.transport.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/funding-secured-sydney-metro-be-reality|publisher=Transport for NSW|date=4 June 2015|accessdate=13 July 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150623191517/http://www.transport.nsw.gov.au/media-releases/funding-secured-sydney-metro-be-reality|archivedate=23 June 2015|df=dmy-all}} and a [[Sydney Metro City & Southwest|second stage]] that will link the [[North Shore, Sydney|North Shore]] to [[Bankstown, NSW|Bankstown]] via a tunnel underneath Sydney Harbour and the CBD is proposed.{{cite web|author1=Transport for NSW|title=Chatswood to Sydenham State Significant Infrastructure Application Report|url=http://sydneymetro.info/home/documents/29887/download|year=2015|accessdate=30 November 2015|location=5.1 Overview and key components|page=56|quote=New metro stations at Crows Nest, Victoria Cross, Barangaroo, Martin Place and Pitt Street, as well as new underground platforms at Central Station|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208072351/http://sydneymetro.info/home/documents/29887/download#|archive-date=8 December 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|last1=Sarah|first1=Gerathy|title=Power vote means Sydney Harbour rail crossing is less than a decade away: NSW Premier Mike Baird|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-06-04/new-sydney-harbour-crossing-at-rocket-speed-after-power-vote/6521304|accessdate=12 November 2015|publisher=ABC News|date=4 June 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151116111125/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-06-04/new-sydney-harbour-crossing-at-rocket-speed-after-power-vote/6521304#|archive-date=16 November 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} Commuter rail's main hub is [[Central railway station, Sydney|Central Railway Station]] ("Central"), located in the southern part of the CBD in [[Haymarket, New South Wales|Haymarket]]: it connects services for almost all of the lines in the [[Sydney Trains]] network, as well as being the terminus for [[NSW TrainLink]] country and inter-urban rail services. There is a largely-underground CBD rail loop, accessed in both directions via Central, which services five additional CBD stations, plus an underground spur line to Bondi Junction which services two. This is known as the [[City Circle]]. The [[Dulwich Hill Line]], the only currently operating light rail line in Sydney (another is under construction) links the southern part of the CBD and Central to nearby suburbs of Sydney's [[Inner-west]]. Buses, both [[State Transit Authority|government-run]] and privately owned, service the CBD along several dozen routes to both inner and more remote suburbs. [[NightRide]] is an after-hours bus service that operates between midnight and 5:00 am, with most services running from George Street outside the Sydney Town Hall.[http://www.transportnsw.info/sites/en/tickets/ticket-types/bus.page#nightride NightRide bus tickets] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151030044712/http://www.transportnsw.info/sites/en/tickets/ticket-types/bus.page#nightride#nightride |date=30 October 2015 }}, Transport NSW Info. Retrieved 5 November 2014 [[Sydney Ferries]] operate largely from [[Circular Quay]], on the northern edge of the CBD. There are several wharves (directly beneath the elevated Circular Quay commuter rail station), with Wharf 3 operating exclusively to [[Manly, New South Wales|Manly]]. There are also ferries at the western edge of the CBD at [[King Street Wharf]], just to the south of [[Barangaroo, New South Wales|Barangaroo]]. == Culture == {{See also|Culture of Sydney}} [[File:Scots Presbyterian Church Sydney (view no. 2).jpg|thumb|right|Scots Presbyterian Church, York Street]] Sydney's culture is compacted within its central business district and inner city ring, due to its nightlife, pedestrian traffic and centrality of notable attractions. There is a large concentration of cultural institutions within the CBD including: the [[Museum of Sydney]], the [[State Library of New South Wales]], the [[Customs House, Sydney|Customs House]] branch of the [[City of Sydney Library]], the [[Theatre Royal, Sydney|Theatre Royal]], the [[City Recital Hall]] and the [[Japan Foundation]]. There are a total of 19 churches located in the Sydney city centre.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sydneyorgan.com/Sydneychurches.html|title=Churches|publisher=sydneyorgan.com|accessdate=22 June 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150622132645/http://www.sydneyorgan.com/Sydneychurches.html#|archive-date=22 June 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} Many other cultural institutions are located at the surrounds of the CBD, such as: the [[Sydney Opera House]] and the [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Sydney|Museum of Contemporary Art]] to the north, the [[Australian Museum]] and the [[Art Gallery of New South Wales]] to the east, the [[Powerhouse Museum]] to the west, [[White Rabbit Gallery]] and the Haymarket branch of the City of Sydney Library to the south. Every January during the summer, the city celebrates with the [[Sydney Festival]]. There are art, music and dance exhibitions at indoor and outdoor venues. Australian and International theatre during the month is also featured, including [[Indigenous Australians|Aboriginal]], and Contemporary. Many of these events are free. The [[Sydney Film Festival]] is an international event organised every year in June at various venues across the CBD. The festival opened on 11 June 1954 and was held over four days, with screenings at Sydney University. Attendance was at full capacity with 1,200 tickets sold at one guinea each.{{cite journal | journal=Senses of Cinema | publisher=Senses of Cinema Inc | title=Looking Back, Looking Forward: the Sydney Film Festival at 50 | author=Kaufman, Tina | date=May 2003 | volume=26 | url=http://www.sensesofcinema.com/2003/festival-reports/sydneyff_50_preview/ | accessdate=25 April 2005 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050415114242/http://www.sensesofcinema.com/contents/festivals/03/26/sydneyff_50_preview.html | archivedate = 15 April 2005}} Sydney boasts a lively café culture, as well as a club and bar scene distributed throughout the CBD and concentrated in a couple of locations such as [[Darling Harbour, New South Wales|Darling Harbour]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sydney.com/destinations/sydney/sydney-city|title=Sydney City|publisher=Destination New South Wales|accessdate=6 April 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130409065231/http://www.sydney.com/destinations/sydney/sydney-city#|archive-date=9 April 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} Although [[Kings Cross, New South Wales|Kings Cross]] is not technically located within the Sydney CBD, it is accessible via William Street, which runs through Hyde Park and is part of the inner-city region. ==Architecture== {{Main|Architecture of Sydney|List of tallest buildings in Sydney}} [[File:MLC 2012.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.7|Podium of the MLC Centre.]] The Sydney CBD contains many of Australia's tallest skyscrapers, including [[Governor Phillip Tower]], [[MLC Centre]] and [[World Tower]], the latter consisting predominantly of apartments. It is also home to Australia's earliest skyscraper, the [[Australia Square]] building on George Street. As of 2017, the tallest structure is [[Centrepoint Tower]] at {{convert|309|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} which has dominated the city skyline since it was topped out in 1981. Recently,{{when|date=March 2017}} height limits for buildings were lifted from {{convert|235|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} to {{convert|310|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}. Sydney's CBD features a juxtaposition of old and new architecture. The old architecture dates back to Sydney's earliest days as a colony, down to the more grandiose Victorian architecture from the Gold rush era–the most substantial examples are the Queen Victoria Building and the Sydney Town Hall. Modern architectures take form as high rises and skyscrapers, which are prolific among all of Sydney's city streets. The earliest skyscraper constructed in Sydney was Culwulla Chambers, which stands at a height of {{convert|50|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} and was completed in 1912. Designed by Spain, Cosh and Minnett, the building consisted of 14 floors and cost £100,000 to build, equivalent of approximately $1 million in today's money.{{cite web|url=http://www.sl.nsw.gov.au/discover_collections/society_art/temples/skyscraper.html|title=Sydney's first skyscraper|work=[[State Library of New South Wales]]|accessdate=11 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140111085854/http://www.sl.nsw.gov.au/discover_collections/society_art/temples/skyscraper.html#|archive-date=11 January 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Demographics== *In the 2016 Census, there were 17,252 people residing in Sydney CBD. The median age was 30 years. Children aged 0 – 14 years made up 4.5% of the population and people aged 65 years and over made up 5.7% of the population. *17.0% of the people were born in Australia. The most common countries of birth were [[Thailand]] (13.3%), China (excludes SARs and Taiwan) (11.7%), [[Indonesia]] (10.7%), [[South Korea]] (5.4%) and [[India]] (3.5%). Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander people made up 0.2% of the population. *25.3% of people only spoke English at home. Other languages spoken at home included [[Mandarin language|Mandarin]] (14.6%), [[Thai language|Thai]] (13.0%), [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] (9.1%), [[Korean language|Korean]] (5.0%) and [[Cantonese language|Cantonese]] (4.2%). *The most common ancestries in the CBD were Chinese (24.6%), [[Thai people|Thai]] (11.3%), English (9.3%), Indonesian (5.1%) and Korean (4.9%). *The most common responses for religion in Sydney CBD were No Religion (31.7%), [[Buddhism]] (21.7%), Not stated (15.8%), [[Catholic]] (12.6%) and [[Anglican]] (3.3%). *18.2% were couple families with children, 65.6% were couple families without children and 8.5% were one parent families. 33.4% were married. *0.2% were separate houses, 0.0% were semi-detached, row or [[terrace house]]s, townhouses etc., 98.9% were flat or apartments and 0.6% were other dwellings. 15.7% of the homes were owned outright, 13.4% were owned with a mortgage and 65.7% were rented. 49.3% were family households, 31.8% were single person households and 18.9% were [[roommate|group households]]. ==Gallery== File:Sydney opera house 2010.jpg|[[Sydney Opera House]] and [[Sydney Harbour Bridge|Harbour Bridge]] File:York Street, Sydney.jpg|[[York Street, Sydney|York Street]] File:State Library of New South Wales Sydney 02.JPG|[[State Library of New South Wales]] File:Sídney-Australia18.JPG|[[Queen Victoria Building]] File:Sydney Conservatorium of Music, Conservatorium Road, Sydney, New South Wales (2011-03-09).jpg|[[Sydney Conservatorium of Music]] File:Sydney Harbour from Australia Hotel from The Powerhouse Museum Collection.jpg|[[Terraced house|Terraced]] buildings, now mostly demolished, looking towards the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Sydney|Royal Botanic Gardens]] and [[Bennelong Point, New South Wales|Bennelong Point]], 1920s File:Aerial view of Sydney Harbour - the bridge is under construction.jpg|View towards Circular Quay, from the North Shore, c. 1930 File:BurnsPhilp.JPG|The central business district features heritage conservation for historic buildings, such as the former [[Burns Philp|Burns Philp Building]] on [[Bridge Street, Sydney|Bridge Street]]. File:SydneyBuilding0002.jpg|19th century York Street apartment building File:QVB night.jpg|The QVB at night File:Sydney Harbour at dusk.jpg|The CBD skyline illuminated at dusk from [[Cremorne Point]] File:Sydney city sunrise.jpg|Sydney city at sunrise. This photo is taken from [[Bondi Junction, New South Wales]] File:Barangaroo111.jpg|Western side of the CBD from Pyrmont == See also == {{Portal|Sydney}} * [[List of tallest buildings in Sydney]] * [[Geography of Sydney]] * [[List of suburbs in Sydney]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Wikivoyage|Sydney/City Centre|Sydney – City Centre}} {{Commons category-inline|Central Business District, Sydney}} {{Sydney regions}} {{Sydney City of Sydney suburbs}} {{Capital city central business districts of Australia}} [[Category:Sydney|Central business district]] [[Category:Central business districts in Australia]] [[Category:Regions of Sydney]] [[Category:Economy of Sydney]]

{{Infobox building | name = The Ogden | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | map_type = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map_size = | map_dot_label = | map_dot_mark = | relief = | former_names = Streamline Tower (until 2011) | alternate_names = | etymology = Ogden Avenue | status = Completed | cancelled = | topped_out = | building_type = Condominiums | architectural_style = | classification = | location = | address = 150 North Las Vegas Boulevard | location_city = [[Downtown Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]] | location_country = United States | coordinates = | altitude = | current_tenants = | namesake = | groundbreaking_date = | start_date = 2006 | stop_date = | est_completion = | topped_out_date = May 2007 | completion_date = | opened_date = May 1, 2008 | inauguration_date = | relocated_date = | renovation_date = 2010
2015 | closing_date = | demolition_date = | cost = | ren_cost = | client = | owner = | landlord = | affiliation = | height = | architectural = | tip = | antenna_spire = | roof = | top_floor = | observatory = | diameter = | circumference = | weight = | other_dimensions = | structural_system = | material = | size = | floor_count = 21 | floor_area = | elevator_count = | grounds_area = | architect = | architecture_firm = PGAL | developer = | engineer = | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | main_contractor = Martin-Harris Construction | awards = | designations = | known_for = | ren_architect = | ren_firm = | ren_engineer = | ren_str_engineer = | ren_serv_engineer = | ren_civ_engineer = | ren_oth_designers = | ren_qty_surveyor = | ren_contractor = | ren_awards = | unit_count = 275 | parking = 428 | website = {{URL|http://ogdenlv.com/}} | embed = | embedded = | references = | footnotes = }} '''The Ogden''' (originally '''Streamline Tower''') is a 21-story luxury [[condominium]] tower located at 150 North Las Vegas Boulevard in [[downtown Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]]. The Ogden was announced in 2004 as the Streamline Tower condominium project, to be built on the former {{convert|1|acre|abbr=on|sing=on}} property of the Golden Inn motel, which was demolished at the end of the year. Work on the property began in 2005, to prepare it for the new project, which began construction the following year. The project was financed by [[Corus Bankshares|Corus Bank]], and was developed by a half-dozen investors, including [[Las Vegas 51s|Las Vegas Stars]] baseball player [[Dusty Allen]]. The tower was [[Topping out|topped off]] in May 2007, and was opened on May 1, 2008. After its opening, Streamline Tower suffered poor sales as the result of a weak local and [[Great Recession in the United States|national economy]]. That year, 48 buyers who had yet to close escrow on their units filed a federal lawsuit against Streamline Tower in an attempt to retrieve their deposit money, after alleging that their units were smaller than expected and that they had been falsely promised the ability to make profits by renting out their units like hotel rooms. In 2009, Corus Bank foreclosed on the property, which was subsequently acquired by ST Residential later that year after the failure of Corus Bank. In 2010, the tower's units were leased to renters. In January 2011, the property was renamed The Ogden, after Ogden Avenue, one of the streets that the building faces. DK Las Vegas purchased the building in 2013, and began renovating and selling the units the following year, as the units' leases ended. ==History== In July 2004, Vegas Valley Properties ([[doing business as]] Streamline Tower LLC){{cite news|last=Curran|first=Stephen|title=The Boulevard of broken dreams|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/apr/05/the-boulevard-of-broken-dreams/|accessdate=March 17, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=April 5, 2005|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318084102/https://lasvegassun.com/news/2005/apr/05/the-boulevard-of-broken-dreams/|archivedate=March 18, 2017|df=}} purchased the Golden Inn motel in [[downtown Las Vegas]], located at the southeast corner of North Las Vegas Boulevard and Ogden Avenue, across from the [[Neonopolis]] mall. In September 2004, the company submitted plans to the city for a 267-foot condominium tower with 251 units and {{convert|24000|sqft|abbr=on}} of commercial space,{{cite news|last=Benston|first=Liz|title=Barrick buys two more properties|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/oct/11/barrick-buys-two-more-properties/|accessdate=March 17, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=October 11, 2004|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318085400/https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/oct/11/barrick-buys-two-more-properties/|archivedate=March 18, 2017|df=}} later reduced to {{convert|12000|sqft|abbr=on}}. The project was being planned by a group of investors led by Patrick McCourt of Barclays North, and [[Dusty Allen]], a former baseball player for the [[Las Vegas 51s|Las Vegas Stars]]. Allen was among a half-dozen investors in the project. Kevin Kelly was also a partner in the project through Vegas Valley Properties. Demolition of the Golden Inn motel began on November 30, 2004, to make room for the Streamline Tower, a 21-story, 251-unit condominium tower that was expected to cost $105 million. Occupancy of the new building was expected around December 2006.{{cite news|title=Streamline Tower project starts|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/nov/30/streamline-tower-project-starts/|accessdate=March 17, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=November 30, 2004|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318085458/https://lasvegassun.com/news/2004/nov/30/streamline-tower-project-starts/|archivedate=March 18, 2017|df=}} Las Vegas Mayor [[Oscar Goodman]] attended a publicity event held on the property, which included him kicking off the demolition of the motel with the swing of a sledgehammer.{{cite news|last=Kalil|first=J.M.|title=The Pitchman|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Dec-19-Sun-2004/news/25112505.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=December 19, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041228195036/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Dec-19-Sun-2004/news/25112505.html|archivedate=December 28, 2004}} The new project would be located in the center of Goodman's planned entertainment district, as part of a revitalization of the downtown area. Sales began on December 3, 2004.{{cite news|last=Schiller Travis|first=Joan|title=Grand opening for Streamline Tower employs 'laws of attraction'|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/real-estate/grand-opening-streamline-tower-employs-laws-attractionreal-estate-paparazzi|accessdate=March 22, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=July 15, 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170323142410/http://www.reviewjournal.com/real-estate/grand-opening-streamline-tower-employs-laws-attractionreal-estate-paparazzi|archivedate=March 23, 2017|df=}} Martin-Harris Construction, the general contractor, had cleared the {{convert|1|acre|abbr=on|sing=on}} site by January 2005, and was preparing to begin construction soon.{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Work on Streamline Tower condominium starting soon|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jan-03-Mon-2005/business/25569094.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=January 3, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050104190344/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jan-03-Mon-2005/business/25569094.html|archivedate=January 4, 2005}} By May 2005, PGAL had been chosen as the project's architect.{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=When will building boom end? Few will say|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/May-02-Mon-2005/business/1312549.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=May 2, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051213075717/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/May-02-Mon-2005/business/1312549.html|archivedate=December 13, 2005}} A nearby sales office at 425 Fremont Street opened on August 12, 2005, at which point Martin-Harris had begun work on the property for the tower.{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Even with signs calling projects under construction, they may not be|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Aug-15-Mon-2005/business/2855998.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=August 15, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051213064713/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Aug-15-Mon-2005/business/2855998.html|archivedate=December 13, 2005}} Approximately $3 million was saved on concrete and steel as a result of the developers locking in prices before [[Hurricane Katrina]].{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Construction costs expected to soar: Rising fuel costs from Hurricane Katrina's damage will have effect on building supplies|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Sep-24-Sat-2005/business/3443941.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=September 24, 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051001030057/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Sep-24-Sat-2005/business/3443941.html|archivedate=October 1, 2005}} Martin-Harris spent six months preparing the site at a cost of $2 million, which included the removal of [[asbestos]]. Martin-Harris was constructing the project's infrastructure in March 2006, while a building permit was purchased for nearly $1 million. By that point, [[Corus Bankshares|Corus Bank]] had agreed to provide financing for the project.{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Groundwork going in for Streamline Tower: Official says company spent six months readying building site|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Mar-13-Mon-2006/business/6268534.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=March 13, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060719153905/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Mar-13-Mon-2006/business/6268534.html|archivedate=July 19, 2006}} The 21-story Streamline Tower was [[Topping out|topped off]] in May 2007,{{cite news|title=Site work under way for Windmill Lane Plaza|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/site-work-under-way-windmill-lane-plaza|accessdate=March 22, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=May 28, 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161011124631/http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/site-work-under-way-windmill-lane-plaza|archivedate=October 11, 2016|df=}} and was scheduled for occupancy in January 2008. At the time, Allen planned to include a restaurant with live music, and was in discussions with a local celebrity chef.{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Up Downtown: Rising condominium projects helping change image of life in city's urban core|url=http://www.lvrj.com/business/8040372.html|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=June 17, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070620084138/http://www.lvrj.com/business/8040372.html|archivedate=June 20, 2007}} A six-story parking garage with 428 parking spaces was also under construction for the new property. To increase sales, a promotion was held later that summer in which five buyers received free [[BMW]] convertible vehicles, worth $37,000 each. The opening was later scheduled to occur in February 2008.{{cite news|last=Schoenmann|first=Joe|title=Mayor loses pounds but hangs on tight to booze|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2008/jan/06/mayor-loses-pounds-hangs-tight-booze/|accessdate=March 22, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=January 6, 2008|quote=There's hope something could work in the building because it is close to Streamline tower, a luxury condo high rise set to open in February.|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170323054156/https://lasvegassun.com/news/2008/jan/06/mayor-loses-pounds-hangs-tight-booze/|archivedate=March 23, 2017|df=}} However, building inspections began that month instead. Allen hoped to obtain a temporary [[certificate of occupancy]] the following month which would allow buyers to close escrow on their units.{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Streamline Tower units nearly ready for residents|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/housing/streamline-tower-units-nearly-ready-residents|accessdate=March 22, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=February 18, 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170323053525/http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/housing/streamline-tower-units-nearly-ready-residents|archivedate=March 23, 2017|df=}} The project was built at a cost of either $125 million{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Hubble|title=Condo buyers struggling for closure amid credit squeeze|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/housing/condo-buyers-struggling-closure-amid-credit-squeeze|accessdate=March 22, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=July 13, 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170323053951/http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/housing/condo-buyers-struggling-closure-amid-credit-squeeze|archivedate=March 23, 2017|df=}} or $205 million. ===Opening and operation=== Streamline Tower ultimately opened on May 1, 2008, with 275 units. The opening had been delayed because of difficulty obtaining a certificate of occupancy. Prices for units ranged from $469,000 to $1.35 million. Because of the poor local and [[Great Recession in the United States|national economy]], only 156 of its units {{ndash}} 57 percent {{ndash}} had been sold, which was the lowest percentage of sales among five major condominium projects in the downtown area. Each of the property's street-level retail spaces also remained vacant after opening.{{cite news|last=Skolnik|first=Sam|title=Quiet on the northern front: Downtown condo tower mostly empty as revitalization efforts limp along|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2008/jun/11/quiet-northern-front/|accessdate=March 22, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=June 11, 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170323053044/https://lasvegassun.com/news/2008/jun/11/quiet-northern-front/|archivedate=March 23, 2017|df=}} In October 2008, 48 buyers who had yet to close escrow on their units filed a federal lawsuit against the property, alleging that their units were smaller than expected and that the property had falsely promised buyers the ability to make profits by renting out their units like hotel rooms. The lawsuit sought the return of each buyer's deposit money. Streamline denied wrongdoing, stating that the claims "are completely refuted by the clear and unambiguous terms" of the purchase agreements. Susan Allen, the sales director for Streamline Tower and the wife of Dusty Allen, stated that sales agents were not supposed to guarantee the leasing of units. Allen also stated that no promises of leasing units had been made during the previous 15 months that she had worked for the project. The plaintiffs also had concerns about the retail spaces on the property, which were still vacant.{{cite news|last=Skolnik|first=Sam|title=Promises unkept? Condo buyers sue|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2008/nov/14/buyers-company-promises-dispute/|accessdate=March 22, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=November 14, 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170323053945/https://lasvegassun.com/news/2008/nov/14/buyers-company-promises-dispute/|archivedate=March 23, 2017|df=}} In November 2008, the property was appraised at $60.3 million, significantly less than the amount loaned by Corus: $104 million. Streamline Tower LLC and other companies related to the project filed for bankruptcy protection in April 2009, halting any further action in the lawsuit. Corus subsequently received permission to foreclose on the property, and was owed $108 million by Streamline Tower LLC. In June 2009, approximately 40 buyers filed a lawsuit to retrieve their deposit money.{{cite news|last=Green|first=Steve|title=Buyers sue for deposit money on downtown condos|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2009/jul/01/buyers-sue-deposits-back-downtown-luxury-condos/|accessdate=March 22, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=July 1, 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170323053956/https://lasvegassun.com/news/2009/jul/01/buyers-sue-deposits-back-downtown-luxury-condos/|archivedate=March 23, 2017|df=}} By August 2009, Corus had begun seeking buyers for the Streamline Tower property, with at least two potential buyers interested, including [[Irwin Molasky|The Molasky Group]]. At that time, the appraised value of the property was $30 million to $35 million, and the building remained operational.{{cite news|last=Skolnik|first=Sam|title=Hard times dash high hopes for downtown's Streamline Tower|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2009/aug/01/hard-times-dash-high-hopes-streamline-tower/|accessdate=March 22, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=August 1, 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170323060142/https://lasvegassun.com/news/2009/aug/01/hard-times-dash-high-hopes-streamline-tower/|archivedate=March 23, 2017|df=}} After the failure of Corus Bank in September 2009,{{cite news|last=Green|first=Steve|title=Regulators seize Corus Bank, plan sale of Vegas projects|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2009/sep/12/regulators-seize-corus-bank-plan-sale-vegas-projec/|accessdate=March 22, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=September 12, 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170323060153/https://lasvegassun.com/news/2009/sep/12/regulators-seize-corus-bank-plan-sale-vegas-projec/|archivedate=March 23, 2017|df=}} ST Residential, a division of Starwood Hotel Group, acquired the Streamline Tower out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy later that year.{{cite news|last=Robison|first=Jennifer|title=Ogden breaks through with $4 million in sales in four weeks|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/economy/ogden-breaks-through-4-million-sales-four-weeks|accessdate=March 17, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=July 24, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170317054914/http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/economy/ogden-breaks-through-4-million-sales-four-weeks|archivedate=March 17, 2017|df=}} In 2010, the building's condominium units were leased, with prices starting at $1,000 per month. The rental concept was to continue for two years, and the company would then evaluate its success and whether to end leasing and sell the units as condominiums. Touch-up work was performed on the building, and included new exterior paint.{{cite news|last=O'Reilly|first=Tim|title=Streamline Tower switches from condominiums to apartments|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/housing/streamline-tower-switches-condominiums-apartments|accessdate=March 17, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=November 27, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170317055056/http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/housing/streamline-tower-switches-condominiums-apartments|archivedate=March 17, 2017|df=}} In January 2011,{{cite news|title=Streamline Tower Renamed The Ogden|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/real-estate/streamline-tower-renamed-ogden|accessdate=March 22, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=January 8, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170323052639/http://www.reviewjournal.com/real-estate/streamline-tower-renamed-ogden|archivedate=March 23, 2017|df=}} the building was renamed as The Ogden, after one of the streets it faces. By 2013, [[Zappos]] [[chief executive officer]] [[Tony Hsieh]] had become a resident in the tower. Hsieh also leased dozens of other units for employees of Zappos and for [[entrepreneur]]s through his [[Tony Hsieh#Career|Downtown Project]]. In January 2013, a small bar with a showroom was being planned for a portion of The Ogden's vacant retail space.{{cite news|last=Schoenmann|first=Joe|title=Bar contemplated for The Ogden|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2013/jan/08/joe-downtown-bar-contemplated-ogden/|accessdate=March 22, 2017|work=Las Vegas Sun|date=January 8, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170323054239/https://lasvegassun.com/news/2013/jan/08/joe-downtown-bar-contemplated-ogden/|archivedate=March 23, 2017|df=}} Private equity firm DK Las Vegas, a partnership of California's KRE Capital and New York's Dune Real Estate Partners, purchased 248 units in the building in December 2013. DK Las Vegas began selling the units as condominiums in October 2014. In March 2015, the company was spending a $2 million budget on upgrades to the units, 40 of which had already been sold. Up to that point, $1.5 million had already been spent, including a $100,000 lobby renovation, a $100,000 improvement of the building's rooftop sky deck, and a $36,500 revamping of the entrance to add new lighting. Other improvements on the rooftop included a desert landscape theme. Condominium improvements included hardwood floors, granite countertops, [[green building]] features, and new lighting. A lounge and outdoor pool were also renovated, as well as all the elevator lobbies. An average of 15 units became available each month in 2015 as rental agreements continued to expire.{{cite news|last=Snel|first=Alan|title=Ogden getting $2 million in upgrades|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/housing/ogden-getting-2-million-upgrades-photos|accessdate=March 17, 2017|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|date=March 19, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318084441/http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/housing/ogden-getting-2-million-upgrades-photos|archivedate=March 18, 2017|df=}} An Asian restaurant and bar, Itsy Bitsy [[Ramen]] and Whisky, opened inside the Ogden in April 2015.{{cite news|last=Chidester|first=Eva|title=Ramen shop moves into the Ogden; paint studio comes to Henderson|url=https://vegasinc.com/news/2015/apr/20/ramen-shop-moves-ogden-paint-studio-comes-henderso/|accessdate=March 22, 2017|work=VegasInc.com|date=April 20, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170323233019/https://vegasinc.com/news/2015/apr/20/ramen-shop-moves-ogden-paint-studio-comes-henderso/|archivedate=March 23, 2017|df=}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://ogdenlv.com/ Official website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060409161051/http://streamlinetower.com/ Streamline Tower official website], archived via the [[Wayback Machine]] {{coord|36.1700|-115.1395|type:landmark_region:US-NV|display=title}} {{Downtown Las Vegas}} {{Las Vegas residential}} {{Las Vegas skyscrapers}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Las Vegas]] [[Category:Downtown Las Vegas]] [[Category:Residential buildings completed in 2008]] [[Category:Residential buildings in the Las Vegas metropolitan area]] [[Category:Residential condominiums in the United States]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Thomas Cawthron | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = 25 May 1833 | birth_place = | death_date ={{dda|1915|10|8|1833|5|25}} | death_place = | nationality = New Zealander | other_names = | known_for = Businessman, philanthropist | occupation = Businessman }} '''Thomas Cawthron''' (25 May 1833 – 8 October 1915) was a New Zealand businessman and philanthropist responsible for the establishment of the [[Cawthron Institute|Cawthron research institute]].<ref name="DNZB Cawthron">{{DNZB|Gee|Margareta|2c13|Cawthron, Thomas 1833?–1915|10 April 2011}}</ref>
Thomas Cawthron was born at [[Newington, Surrey]], on 25 May 1833 and was 15 years old when his parents and family set out for [[Nelson, New Zealand]], in the sailing ship ''Mary''. He worked in Wellington, then followed the gold miners to Australia, spending several years as a contractor for miscellaneous goods on the [[Victorian gold rush|goldfields]] of [[Bendigo]] and [[Ballarat]].
Returning to Nelson in the mid-1850s when his father became ill, he won a contract to dig the test drives for copper deposits on the Dun Mountain, going on to contract for the supply of food and stores for the copper-mining project and for the Jenkins Hill coal mine. He delivered supplies to miners in the rough Mineral Belt country, around 20 km away by a mountainous track from the Nelson township. Many fortunes were made and lost in New Zealand’s 19th century gold rushes. Cawthron invested in property, shares, local bodies, war loans and mortgages and seemed to have a ‘golden touch’ in all his business transactions. A canny merchant, he amassed his wealth from offices in the beached hulk of a ship at Nelson, but most of his money came through the hunt for coal and copper and from sending supplies to gold miners in [[Golden Bay]] and [[Hokitika]]. By the time of his retirement in the late 1880s, he had amassed a considerable fortune.
After his retirement, he lived quietly and frugally with his sister Mrs Wright. He seemed to have few interests other than the investment and care of his money. However, behind the scenes, he helped out in many individual cases of hardship and distress and contributed to causes such as relief funds, church organisations and educational and recreational schemes. In his later years, he made larger and more public gifts, including the Cathedral steps, the Rocks Road chains, Cawthron Park (in the hills to the east of the city), contributions towards a public hospital and nurses' home, and smaller donations to the Nelson Institute (which used to run the Nelson library), the Nelson School of Music and its pipe organ.
Thomas Cawthron died on 8 October 1915. He bequeathed £231,000, practically the whole of his estate, for the development of an industrial and technical school, institute and museum to be called the Cawthron Institute. This was officially opened in 1921 with [[Thomas Hill Easterfield]], emeritus professor of chemistry at [[Victoria University College]], as its first director.
== References == {{Reflist}}
==Sources== *Theodore Rigg, Encyclopaedia of New Zealand. 1966; *Karen Stade, www.theprow.org.nz 2009.
==External links== *[http://www.cawthron.org.nz The Cawthron Institute]
{{Authority control}}

{{EngvarB|date=February 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{BLP sources|date=January 2013}} {{Malay name|Vivy Sofinas|Yusof}} {{Infobox person | name = Datin Vivy Yusof | image = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1987|12|11}} | birth_place = [[Kajang, Selangor]], [[Malaysia]] | occupation = [[TV Personality]], Co-founder of FashionValet and The dUCk Group | spouse = Dato' Fadzarudin Shah Anuar Ibrahim (m.2012) | children = Daniel Azim Shah Mariam Iman Shah Sarah Ilham Shah
| birthname = Vivy Sofinas Binti Yusof Jusoh }}
'''Datin Vivy Yusof''' is an entrepreneur and the co-founder of FashionValet and The dUCk Group. Vivy is a blogging veteran of 10 years who has been sharing insights about her life and entrepreneurial journey through her personal blog, www.proudduck.com<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.proudduck.com/|title=PROUDDUCK|website=www.proudduck.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-07}}</ref>
== Career == A law graduate from London School of Economics (LSE),<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.asianentrepreneur.org/vivy-sofinas-yusof-fashionvalet-interview/|title=Vivy Sofinas Yusof, Co-Founder of FashionValet - Asian Entrepreneur|last=Ting|first=Henry|date=2016-04-05|work=Asian Entrepreneur|access-date=2017-06-07|language=en-US}}</ref> Vivy is the Chief Creative Officer at FashionValet,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fashionvalet.com/|title=FASHIONVALET {{!}} Shop Asia's biggest designer brands online {{!}} Shop women's clothes, shoes, bags & accessories {{!}} FashionValet|website=www.fashionvalet.com|language=en|access-date=2017-06-07}}</ref> a fashion e-commerce company founded by herself and her husband, Dato' Fadzarudin Shah Anuar (mostly known as Fadza), in 2010 when they were 23 years old. Now a multi-million dollar company with 150 employees and carrying 500 fashion brands, FashionValet has offices and warehouses in Malaysia, Jakarta and Singapore, and ships parcels daily to customers all over the world.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theedgemarkets.com/article/venture-fashion-valet%E2%80%99s-ambitions-will-never-be-just-about-e-commerce|title=Venture: Fashion Valet’s ambitions will never be just about e-commerce|date=2017-04-21|work=The Edge Markets|access-date=2017-06-07}}</ref>
Vivy currently oversees the brand image and handles collaborations and PR with her connections in the media and fashion industry.
Following the success of FashionValet, Vivy Yusof launched dUCk to convey the message that wearing scarves should be a celebrated act among women, whether Muslim or not.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://duckscarves.com/about-duck/|title=About dUCk {{!}} dUCk|website=duckscarves.com|access-date=2017-01-11}}</ref>
Vivy has won several awards including; Bella Business Award 2013,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.budiey.com/ntv7-umum-senarai-finalis-top-5-bella-awards-2013/|title=ntv7 Umum Senarai Finalis Top 5 Bella Awards 2013|last=https://plus.google.com/+BudieyIsma/posts|date=2013-01-24|website=www.budiey.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-07}}</ref> Ikon Wanita Puteri UMNO 2014<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.panduanmalaysia.com/2014/11/senarai-penerima-anugerah-ikon-wanita.html|title=Senarai Penerima Anugerah Ikon Wanita Puteri UMNO 2014|website=www.panduanmalaysia.com|access-date=2017-06-07}}</ref> Prestige Magazine's 2015 List of Top 40 Under 40,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://prestigeonline.com/my/People/The-Lists/40-Under-40-2015/Vivy-Yusof|title=Vivy Yusof - 40 Under 40 2015|access-date=2017-06-07|language=en}}</ref> Women's Weekly Malaysia's Finance and Commerce Nominee for the Great Women of Time Awards 2015,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://womensweekly.my/women-we-love/great-women-of-our-time-awards/finance-commerce-nominee-2015-vivy-yusof/|title=Finance & Commerce Nominee 2015: Vivy Yusof – The Malaysian Women's Weekly|date=2015-11-13|work=The Malaysian Women's Weekly|access-date=2017-06-07|language=en-US}}</ref> 60 Wanita Inspirasi Nona,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nona.my/highlight/happening-today-60-wanita-inspirasi-nona-1.450632|title=Happening Today: 60 Wanita Inspirasi Nona|last=Nona|first=Web|website=www.nona.my|access-date=2017-06-07}}</ref> Young Entrepreneur Award from Tribute To Women Malaysia (the award was presented to Vivy by Her Majesty Raja Permaisuri Agong Tuanku Hajah Haminah),<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.elle.my/celebrity/News/Vivy-Yusof-Neelofa-and-Pandelela-Rinong-receive-Tribute-to-Women-2016-awards|title=Vivy Yusof, Neelofa and Pandelela honoured at Tribute to Women gala|last=Malaysia|first=ELLE|work=ELLE Malaysia|access-date=2017-06-07}}</ref> Top 5 in Meletop Era's 2017 Fashion category,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.astrogempak.com.my/artikel/4129/senarai-penuh-calon-top-5-ame-2017-neelofa-mendominasi-raih-5-pencalonan|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and Anugerah Bintang Popular Berita Harian's 2017 Top 5 Social Media Personality<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.budaklelaki.com/2017/05/anugerah-bintang-popular-berita-harian.html|title=Senarai Top 5 Anugerah Bintang Popular Berita Harian 2017 (ABPBH 3.0)|website=www.budaklelaki.com|access-date=2017-06-07}}</ref>
Vivy has also graced the covers of several high-profile magazines in Malaysia - HerWorld,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/HerWorldMalaysia/videos/10155489992696874/|title=Her World Malaysia|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2017-06-07}}</ref> Prestige,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://prestigeonline.com/my/People/Personalities/Cover-story-Vivy-Yusof|title=5 Key Quotes from Vivy Yusof|access-date=2017-06-07|language=en}}</ref> and Tatler.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://my.asiatatler.com/society/of-chemistry-and-affection-vivy-yusof-and-fadza-anuar-on-building-fashionvalet|title=Of Chemistry And Affection: Vivy Yusof And Fadza Anuar On Building Their Empire, FashionValet|work=Malaysia Tatler|access-date=2017-06-07|language=en}}</ref> She was also named a Friend of Louis Vuitton, being the first hijabi woman to be honored with the title.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nst.com.my/news/2016/07/159537/tale-two-vs|title=A tale of two Vs|date=2016-07-20|work=NST Online|access-date=2017-06-07|language=en}}</ref> Vivy was listed on Tatler's 2017 Generation T list - a group of next generation industry leaders in their region<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://my.asiatatler.com/society/wearegenerationt-meet-our-connectors|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and its Top 50 Rising Tech Stars in Asia.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://my.asiatatler.com/society/asia-s-top-50-rising-tech-stars-the-malaysian-contingent|title=Asia’s Top 50 Rising Tech Stars: The Malaysian Contingent|work=Malaysia Tatler|access-date=2017-06-07|language=en}}</ref>
She has been featured in many international media including BBC,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/capital/story/20151214-how-muslim-headscarves-became-a-huge-fashion-empire|title=How Muslim headscarves became a fashion empire|last=Mayberry|first=Kate|access-date=2017-06-07}}</ref> The New York Times,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nytlive.nytimes.com/womenintheworld/2015/12/24/malaysian-entrepreneur-glams-up-the-hijab/|title=Malaysian entrepreneur glams up the hijab|date=2015-12-24|work=Women in the World in Association with The New York Times - WITW|access-date=2017-06-07|language=en-US}}</ref> and Forbes.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/cmalasig/2016/09/28/the-malaysian-entrepreneur-who-built-an-online-empire-with-personal-branding/#6563a8e71e2c|title=The Malaysian Businesswoman Using Personal Branding To Build An Empire|last=Ramoran-Malasig|first=Carolyn|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-06-07}}</ref> Well-acclaimed as one of Malaysia's top bloggers with 250K hits monthly on her blog, Proudduck, Vivy has been blogging for ten years and is still actively involved in her blog. Vivy is also a social media icon with over a million followers on Instagram. Recently, in 2017, Vivy started venturing into [[Vlog|vlogging]] as well besides blogging, where she launched her own channel on YouTube<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCHY0v1pMghChYoUAOkqHkhQ/featured?disable_polymer=1|title=Vivy Yusof|website=YouTube|language=en|access-date=2018-03-06}}</ref>, serving as the visual platform to share her life insights with her followers on regular basis.
She regularly attends fashion events in the Southeast Asia region as a fashion expert and social media influencer.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.digitalfashionweek.com/dfw-insider-info/vivy-yusof/|title=DFW Insider Info - Digital Fashion Week 2016|work=Digital Fashion Week 2016|access-date=2017-06-07|language=en-US}}</ref> Vivy has also participated for two years as a judge for AirAsia's Runway Ready Designer Search, where she and a panel of judges travel throughout Southeast Asia in search for the next big name in Asian fashion.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/features/article/airasia-expands-fashion-designer-search-2017-to-all-ten-asean-countries|title=AirAsia expands fashion designer search 2017 to all 10 Asean countries|date=2017-02-09|access-date=2017-06-07}}</ref>
Vivy and her husband, Fadza, were officially welcomed into Endeavor<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.endeavormalaysia.org/vivy-yusof/|title=Vivy Yusof - Endeavor|date=2017-03-08|work=Endeavor|access-date=2017-06-07|language=en-US}}</ref> - a global organisation that "selects, mentors and accelerates high-impact entrepreneurs".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.endeavormalaysia.org/about-us/|title=About - Endeavor|work=Endeavor|access-date=2017-06-07|language=en-US}}</ref> Fadza and Vivy are the first Malays to be a part of Endeavor team.
In April 2017, Vivy was listed on Forbes as one of Asia's Top 30 under 30.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/pictures/hdfl45iei/vivy-yusof-29/#a09c8c896b2d|title=Vivy Yusof, 29 - pg.3|last=Wehbe|first=Rana|website=Forbes|access-date=2017-06-07}}</ref>
== Television == In 2012, Vivy Yusof and Fadzarudin Shah Anuar attained first place on ''Make The Pitch'', a reality television show where the duo won RM1million investment by MyEG Services Bhd, for a 30% stake in the company.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.digitalnewsasia.com/sizzle-fizzle-slow-burn/fashionvalet-more-than-makes-the-grade-on-make-the-pitch|title=FashionValet more than makes the grade on Make The Pitch|date=2012-10-16|newspaper=Digital News Asia|access-date=2017-01-11}}</ref>{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} Vivy later starred in [[Astro Ria]]'s reality television series, ''Love, Vivy''.<ref>{{Citation|last=fashionvalet|title=Introducing Love, Vivy|date=2016-04-11|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qjbLoCkrukw|accessdate=2017-01-11}}</ref>{{citation needed|date=January 2016}}
''Love, Vivy'' revolves around the life of one of Malaysia's leading faces in fashion — juggling her work, keeping on top of their leading online retail empire FashionValet and her scarf brand, dUCk, as well as her family duties as daughter, wife, and mother to two children, Daniel Azim Shah and Mariam Iman Shah.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/showbiz/article/reality-show-on-mompreneur-vivy-yusof-to-air-on-astro-ria|title=Reality show on ‘mompreneur’ Vivy Yusof to air on Astro RIA|date=2016-04-07|access-date=2017-01-11}}</ref>
On 21 February 2017, the second season of ''Love, Vivy'' was aired on [[Astro Ria]].
==References== {{reflist}}

{{For|the earlier confederate executive mansion|First White House of the Confederacy}} {{Infobox NRHP | name =White House of the Confederacy | nrhp_type = nhl | designated_other1 = Virginia Landmarks Register | designated_other1_date = September 9, 1969<ref name=register>{{cite web|title=Virginia Landmarks Register|url=http://www.dhr.virginia.gov/registers/register_counties_cities.htm|publisher=Virginia Department of Historic Resources|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref> | designated_other1_number = 127-0115 | designated_other1_num_position = bottom | designated_other2 = Richmond City Historic District | designated_other2_name = Richmond City Historic District | designated_other2_abbr = | designated_other2_color = | designated_other2_link = Richmond,_Virginia#Historic_Districts | image = 2015 Confederate White House - Richmond, Virginia.JPG | caption = White House of the Confederacy, 2015 | location= Clay and 12th Sts., [[Richmond, Virginia]] | coordinates = {{coord|37|32|27|N|77|25|47|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = Virginia#USA | area = | built =1818 | architect= attributed to [[Robert Mills (architect)|Robert Mills]] | architecture= [[Neoclassical architecture|Neoclassical]] (1818 construction); [[Greek Revival]] (1844 modifications); [[Italianate]] (1857 additions) | designated_nrhp_type= December 19, 1960<ref name="nhlsum">{{cite web|url=http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=703&ResourceType=Building |title=White House of the Confederacy|accessdate=2008-06-27|work=National Historic Landmark summary listing|publisher=National Park Service}}</ref> | added = October 15, 1966<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2008a}}</ref> | governing_body = Private | refnum=66000924 }} The '''White House of the Confederacy''' is a historic house located in the [[Court End]] neighborhood of [[Richmond, Virginia]]. Built in 1818, it was the main executive residence of the sole [[President of the Confederate States of America]], [[Jefferson Davis]], from August 1861 until April 1865. It was viewed as the [[Confederate States of America|Confederate States]] counterpart to the [[White House]] in Washington, D.C.<ref>{{cite web|title=White House of the Confederacy |url=https://acwm.org/calendar-events/white-house-of-the-confederacy |website=[[American Civil War Museum]] |accessdate=2018-02-03}}</ref>
Since the late 19th century, it has been a [[house museum]] operated by the [[American Civil War Museum]] and is known as the White House and Museum of the Confederacy. It was designated a [[National Historic Landmark]] in 1960.
==History== The [[First White House of the Confederacy]] in [[Montgomery, Alabama]] was the first official residence of the President and his family. The second White House of the Confederacy is a gray stuccoed neoclassical mansion built in 1818 by [[John Brockenbrough]], who was president of the Bank of Virginia. Designed by [[Robert Mills (architect)|Robert Mills]], Brockenbrough's private residence was built in early nineteenth century on East Clay Street in [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]]'s affluent [[Shockoe Hill]] neighborhood (later known as the [[Court End]] District), and was two blocks north of the Virginia State Capitol. Among his neighbors were [[U.S. Chief Justice]] [[John Marshall]], [[Aaron Burr]], defense attorney [[John Wickham (attorney)|John Wickham]], and future U.S. Senator [[Benjamin Watkins Leigh]].
Sold by the Brockenbrough family in 1844, the house passed through a succession of wealthy families throughout the [[antebellum South|antebellum]] period, including U.S. Congressman and future Confederate Secretary of War [[James Seddon]]. Just prior to the [[American Civil War]], Lewis Dabney Crenshaw purchased the house and added a third floor. He sold the home to the City of Richmond, which in turn rented it to the Confederate government as its Executive Mansion.
===Davis family=== [[File:LC-B815-911 Rt side stereoview 1865 LOC.JPG|thumb|left|White House of the Confederacy, 1865, Library of Congress]] [[Jefferson Davis]], his wife [[Varina Howell|Varina]], and their children moved into the house in August 1861, and lived there for the remainder of the war. Davis suffered from recurring bouts with [[malaria]], facial [[neuralgia]], [[cataract]]s (in his left eye), unhealed wounds from the [[Mexican–American War|Mexican War]] (bone spurs in his heel), and insomnia. Consequently, President Davis maintained an at-home office on the second floor of the White House. This was not an unusual practice at that time – the West Wing of the White House in Washington, DC, was not added until the [[Theodore Roosevelt]] administration. President Davis' personal secretary, Colonel [[Burton Harrison]], also lived in the house.
The Davis family was quite young during their stay at the White House of the Confederacy. When they moved in, the family consisted of the President and First Lady, six-year-old Margaret, four-year-old Jefferson Davis, Jr., and two-year-old Joseph. The two youngest Davis children, William and [[Winnie Davis|Varina Anne ("Winnie")]], were born in the White House, in 1861 and 1864, respectively. Among their neighborhood playmates was [[George S. Patton (attorney)|George Smith Patton, Sr.]], whose [[George S. Patton, Sr.|father]] commanded the [[22nd Virginia Infantry]], and whose [[George S. Patton|son]] commanded the [[U.S. Third Army]] in World War Two. Joseph Davis died in the spring of 1864, after a 15-foot fall from the railing on the White House's east portico. Mrs. Davis' mother and sister were occasional visitors to the Confederate executive mansion. [[File:Ord & Staff South Portico WHC-1865 - LC- B78.JPG|thumb|Maj.Gen. [[E.O.C. Ord]] and staff on the South Portico of the White House of the Confederacy, 1865, Library of Congress]] The house was abandoned during the evacuation of Richmond on April 2, 1865. Within twelve hours, soldiers from Major General [[Godfrey Weitzel]]'s XVIII Corps seized the former Confederate White House, intact. President [[Abraham Lincoln]], who was in nearby City Point (now [[Hopewell, Virginia]]), traveled up the James River to tour the captured city, and visited Davis' former residence for about three hours – although the President only toured the first floor, feeling it would be improper to visit the more private second floor of another man's home. Admiral [[David Dixon Porter]] accompanied Lincoln during the visit to the former Confederate executive mansion. They held a number of meetings with local officials in the White House. Among them was Confederate Brigadier General [[Joseph Reid Anderson]], who owned the [[Tredegar Iron Works]].
===After the war=== During [[Reconstruction Era of the United States|Reconstruction]], the White House of the Confederacy served as the headquarters for Military District Number One (Virginia), and was occasionally used as the residence of the commanding officer of the Department of Virginia. Among those who served there were Major Generals [[Edward O.C. Ord]], [[Alfred Terry]], [[Henry Halleck]], and [[Edward R.S. Canby]]. When Reconstruction ended in Virginia, (October 1870), the City of Richmond retook possession of the house, and subsequently used it as Richmond Central School, one of the first public schools in postwar Richmond.
When the City announced its plans to demolish the building to make way for a more modern school building in 1890, the [[Confederate Memorial Literary Society]] was formed with the sole purpose of saving the White House from destruction.
==See also== * [[American Civil War Museum]] * [[List of National Historic Landmarks in Virginia]] * [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Richmond, Virginia]]
